bibl.title: Letter from Anita Clayton Blincoe to Caroline Latimer, March 3, 1906

div1.p: Blincoe sends Latimer the obituary of Laura Reed Blincoe, who was Walter Reed's sister.

div1.head: Letter from Anita Clayton Blincoe to Caroline Latimer, March 3, 1906
div1.opener:
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
Ashland Va
March 3rd 1906
My dear Miss Latimer
div1.p:
Your
letter to my mother came
the day of her funeral.
I enclose a very correct
notice. My father's
name was James William
Blincoe; of course you
want only his initials. Since
September 1st, when we found
that our dear Mother was ill
with an incurable disease;
it has been my great
desire for Dr Kelly to see
her, But people who knew
better than I, assured me
that it would be useless
to take her to see him,
as there was no hope
of prolonging her sweet
life. I shall be very
grateful if the book which
was intended for her can be
sent to me,

div1.head: OBITUARY
div1.p:
ASHLAND, VA., Feb. 28.--(Special.)--
Mrs. Laura Reed Blincoe, widow of the
Rev. J. W. Blincoe, of the Methodist Epis-
copal Church South, died in Virginia hos-
pital in RICHMOND this morning at
five o'clock after a long illness, 65 years
cid.

Mrs. Blincoe was a lady of rare Chris-
tian character, whose bright and lovely
nature made her beloved by all. She was
the sister of the Rev. J. C. Reed, of the
Methodist church, and the late Dr. Wal-
ter Reed, of the United States army.
Mrs. Blincoe leaves four daughters,
Misses Nita and Laura Blincoe, of Ash-
land; Mrs. Graves, of Lynchburg; Mrs.
Thomas Phelphs, of Bowling Green, and
three sons, Messrs. Lemuel, Paul and
Olin Blincoe, of Norfolk.

She is also survived by three brothers,
the Rev. J. C. Reed, of Lynchburg; Mr.
Thomas W. Reed, of Kansas; Mr. Chris-
topher Reed, of Utah, and one sister,
Mrs. D. T. Elam, of Farmville, Va. The
funeral takes place at four o'clock to-
morrow afternoon from Duncan-Me-
morial church and the burial will be in
Woodlawn cemeter.
